Firstly you need to have some past with web application developing and Java Core.

I studied Java SE myself more than 1 year. Also from the school We learnt fundamentals of Programming, Web, Protocols, Web Developing(ASP.net, php) and so on.

I desire to work on enterprise level development and I have past to take this course. I definetly not recommend if you just write hello world in web. 

As me, if you're interested on web development with Java EE and you're at just beginning of Java EE Web or Spring Framework (but as I mentioned it's better to have web development fundamental knowledge and core web  programming skills) I definetely recommend.

results.content:
Finally I built a cool music store by following this 14-hour tutorial. It took me about 2-weeks. Though it seems simple to just follow the instructor and type code line by line, it takes some time to understand what each line of code do and how to implement model-view-controller design pattern. Also, you will have to debug the code by reading the error information. The debugging is sometimes demanding but really rewarding.
This course connects many "dots" for me. I have some Java and Spring framework knowledge but never had a chance to build a real website. Thanks to the course, I can finally use the skills I have and learn new skills along the way. I have much deeper understanding of how a website work from front-end to back-end.

results.content:
This course is great for beginners to get to grips with the Spring framework in a really practical hands on approach which is better for those who prefer this kind of approach. The teaching is great and the support from the lecturer is better than most courses on Udemy.

However, the application created is an unfinished and barely reliable application for a real e-commerce store with orders created before the user agreed to make the order and no payment information being taken in. The business flow is wrong as well with no cart being created for non-registered customers who should be given the option to sign up before proceeding to the checkout.

I feel more features should be added to the application as it does feel unfinished and needs refining in my opinion.

response.content:
Hi Daniel,

Thanks for taking the course and thoughtful inputs here. Yes, the website is not finished and some of the business flow definitely needs to be refined. 
E-Commerce website could be tremendously complex like Amazon and in general is not something you can quick develop and expect a mature product. The point in this course is to quickly show you how to use Spring Framework to build an App from GUI to database. Even just test for an app of this size, depending on the size of team, it could take half a year from test planning to test execution. Anyway, I still appreciate your honest ideas here. Good luck!

Best,
Le

response.content:
Hi Sergine,

Sorry to hear that you your license expired. You can still use Eclipse to follow the course. IDE is just a tool. It's been regarded that Intellij is the IDE that Java developers want to try out the most. A lot of students are familiar with Eclipse, or you can find tutorials on it. Yet, there aren't many about Intellij out there. Hence, I would like to take this opportunity to get students to start using Intellij, because there are some really good features with it. Plus, if you qualify, intellij has a student program to provide a free account for a year.

Best,
Le

results.content:
I may not be target audience for this course, but this is, by far, one of the poorest course that I have taken on udemy.

Idea of building ecommerce website from scratch is more then welcome to have, if it is done properly. However a cannot leave, without pointing at some of the crucial flaws:
Firstly: there seems to be no preparation of code in this course. Author makes a lot of typing mistakes and sometimes even rewrites the whole code. I am all with making intentional errors to make a point, but having lots of typos is just a waste of time for everyone.
Second: having music at the end and at the beginning of the each lecture is more then irritating.
Third: good luck if you have small monitor as author did not bother to increase font size in his intellij. I have 24 inch monitor (1920x1080) and I was still struggling to read code properly.
Fourth: author should consider that some of us are really not interested in looking at jsp/html/css code. They should, of course, be available for completeness, but do not mix frontend and backend work in one lecture!!! Separate backend and frontend lecture so that people can skip them if they desire. Separation of concepts (backend and frontend) is a good programming practice as well.
Fifth: tons of bad programming practices. Some of the practices might not be so bad for someone who starts with the programming, but some of the practices should not be teach and encouraged even for beginners! Example: Using plural names instead of singular names as hibernate entity tables is a very very bad practice. Rest API design for this application is totally misleading (using PUT method to delete an item ?!?!? on /remove/{productId} url ?!?!?)

I have taken some other courses by this author and he has some very neat and great courses so I assume that time constraints that he had have affected on the overall quality of this course.

results.content:
I already had some knowledge of Spring and Hibernate. But have not done a full fledged  project on same. This was a good experience understanding how various concepts of Spring , Hibernate, Restful can be combined together. How classes can be designed, how to separate DAO, Service and Controllers . Best Industry practices followed. 
I feel more confident to face interviews. Thanks a lot Le Deng for preparing this Course, its a kick start course for one's who are looking forward to work on projects using these Technologies. I wish I could find such a content few years back.

results.content:
I have a "love and hate" relation with this course so far.
Love: I learn something. Something here is from F End to Back End.  
Hate:
1/ The music is so distracting, English is not my mother language, so my English is also as broken as the speaker, but  why overcharge the broken, monotone English with annoying, distracting music?
2/People already complained about dark IntellJ background + tiny fonts.  I repeat.

I wonder why the teacher does not pay attention to all these details but important issues?!!!! Students want to learn something and so annoyed, frustrated by NO-ERGONOMIC factors like that!!!!

Redo your course smoother, and you will get 5 stars.

Version 2 of the review:

I go forward in the course, the good point of the course is it connects the dot, we see how different technologies assembled, besides JS, we also see how AngularJS is used.  I understand perfectly that it needs another course/tutorial on AngularJS to understand better what Le explained, but it's OK to give a spoon of AngularJS to taste.

I still have same assessment on the course:
- Good: Practical course, connect the dots
- Bad: Distracting music makes broken English hard to understand (don't get me wrong, I have same name Le as the teacher, no discrimination here, just a very friendly observation)

I raise my assessment to 3.5 stars, because  practical, connecting-dot courses are rare.  The effort to introduce new technology like AngularJS is meritorious. Thank you.

results.content:
This is by far one of the best online courses I have taken.  With prior background in Java, this course was just what I needed to get my feet wet with Java Spring Framework and AngularJS. I liked the fact that the instructor does not take shortcuts and starts with a simple concept that he continues to build upon. I highly recommend it anyone who wants to start doing web application development.
The instructor really knows a lot about Spring Framework and is very helpful in assisting whenever I got stuck.
